This discussion started on a prior thread (evolving religion), but it seemed interesting enough to warrant its own topic, so here goes. I posit that there is no such thing as Absolute Truth.
 
 Since the discussion up until now has been sorely lacking for a hard definition of the word, here's how "truth" is defined at dictionary.com - there's one phrase that seems to be what we're looking for:
 
 Truth:
 "That which is considered to be the supreme reality and to have the ultimate meaning and value of existence."
 
 Let's deconstruct that sentence, starting with "supreme reality." Is there such a thing? Yes, in that there is an objective universe that consists of physical objects and laws that exists outside of our perceptions of it. Your brain gives you your own reality; a muddied, filtered version of the external one for you to interact with. A change in our internal reality doesn't change the objective world itself. A color-blind view of an apple won't change the way that light strikes the surface and releases photons in a specific manner.
 
 Next part of the sentence: "ultimate meaning." Meaning is something that is constructed in our own internal realities, which we've established is separate from the "supreme reality" of the objective world outside us. There is no meaning to an apple, to a horse or a skyscraper. They simply are. Our brains, which are hardwired to draw connections, examine relationships between objects and assign meanings which will help us relate to those around us and successfully raise another generation of humans. If there is an "ultimate meaning" that all humans can agree on (yeah, right), it still would have no actual connection to the physical universe.
 
 "Value of existence." Same as "ultimate meaning." Value, used this way, is an internal concept. The 9/11 hijackers valued their existence much differently than the citizens they condemned valued theirs. 
 
 So, given that Meaning and Value, which comprise Truth as defined above, exist only in our internal realities, which don't have any effect on the objective universe around us, it follows that there is no Absolute Truth.
 
 Finally, stating that "there is no absolute truth" is not just stating another absolute truth. Truth, as we've established, is a human construct, and our argument has nothing to say about Meaning and Value.
